title: In Chapter 7 bankruptcy, if I do not have pay stubs
question: If I do not have pay stubs to show, could I show bank statements highlighting the deposits from pay from self-employment income? Why are we asked to show pay stubs?
answers:
The law requires pay advices. Many trustees look for some proof of income. The last six months income is needed for the means test and the last 60 days is needed for the trustee. If you do not have paystubs, do you have something else that shows how you are paid. Bank statements only show deposits, but not total paid. You need to show gross, not net (which is what bank statements show).

The code has many requirements like this that add to the paperwork load. Welcome to Bankruptcy Reform.

Why? Because in 2005 the U.S. Bankruptcy Code was amended requiring that you qualify for a chapter 7 through a means test using the last 6 months of income. And also, the code requires that you submit to the trustee, before your creditor's meeting, "payment advices" for the 60 day period before the date of your filing. People who get pay stubs have the easiest time of this. However, where you are self employed, if you deposit all of your receipts in one account, and pay your expenses from that account, yes, the statements of that account covering the 60-day period prior to the date that you filed your petition.

And, if you ask "why" again, I will refer you to whoever your congressional representative was in the year 2005. We attorneys are not so good with the "why" questions. Our task is to apply the laws as they are.

I highly advise you to retain an experienced bankruptcy attorney in your jurisdiction to guide you through the complexities of bankruptcy law and procedure.

Good luck!

If you are self employed you usually need to put together a profit and loss statement, and/or file a small business report, along with supporting bank statements. The key is you just need to be able to clearly document your income.
